fields.bodyText: Last Tuesday’s Mid Year Fiscal and Economic Outlook (Myefo) revealed a pretty bleak assessment of the future: growth was revised down, unemployment was revised up. It’s been that kind of year, a year that has had a fair bit of negativity on the economic front, but which has seen Australia suffer a little bit from unnecessary pessimism. Our unemployment rate for example of 5.8% might be higher than it has been for most of the past 10 years, but the 20 year average rate for Australia is 6.3%, so it is worthwhile not always judging everything according to the best of times. It hasn’t been a horror economic year, but neither will anyone be organising a parade to celebrate how good it has been. So let’s cast our eye over some of the major aspects of the economy from GDP to investment, jobs, inflation and spending. GDP growth The big downgrade in the budget bottom line from $30.1bn to $47bn is due to revisions to the forecasts GDP growth figures. The latest GDP figures showed our economy was growing by 2.3% in real terms. This is generally considered to be below trend growth as over the past 30 years average annual growth is 3.4%. Click to view graphic on mobile Nominal GDP growth (ie GDP growth in current dollars, not adjusted for inflation) also remains well below average levels. For the past year it grew at only 3.5% – well below the average of 6.35% and a mere one percentage point above real growth. This means Australia is experiencing low inflation but because nominal GDP severely affects tax receipts it also means the government will receive a lower amount of revenue than it expected. This is a big issue for the revised budget position. The Myefo revised down nominal GDP growth for 2013-14 from 3.75% to 3.5% and for 2014-15 from 4.5% to 3.5%. That remains historically low especially given it forecasts real GDP to grow by 2.5% in 2014-15. This revision of nominal GDP caused a write down from the pre-election fiscal and economic outlook (PEFO) of $36.8bn in tax receipts estimates and a subsequent increase in expenses (through unemployment benefits and the like) of $17.8bn. This by itself increased the cumulative level of deficits over the next four years by $54bn out of the overall increase of $68bn in cumulative deficits predicted in the Myefo. If there is one measure that will be more likely to improve the budget bottom line than any other, it will be if this estimate for nominal GDP growth turns out to be overly pessimistic. Looking overseas for some context, Australia’s economic performance has fallen somewhat compared with other countries. Twelve months ago we had the fourth fastest growing economy in the OECD; now it is ninth. For those in Europe, such a problem no doubt elicits a pretty hollow laugh. The Euro zone remains the place where economic growth goes to die, and even the UK’s better than expected growth of 1.7% has it losing the economic Ashes contest: Click here to view graphic on a mobile Investment But while Australia’s growth has been tempered in the past year, there is some small cause for optimism in the level of investment observed this year. Given the importance of the mining industry to our national economy, the end of the investment phase of the mining boom had many worried that investment would crash. Fortunately the latest capital expenditure figures show more of a plateau than a sharp decline. Mining investment is holding up quite well. The manufacturing industry however continues its poor performance. Click here to view on a mobile Again here the Myefo is quite pessimistic. It forecasts a fall in business investment of 1.5% in 2013-14 and of 2% in 2014-15 compared to the previous estimates of a growth in investment in this year of 1.5% and a fall in 2014-15 of just 0.5%. The level of investment decline is important because while actual economic growth might hold up as mining exports increase, as has oft been noted, the production/export phase of the boom won’t lead to as many jobs as did the investment boom. Employment This year we saw unemployment rise from 5.4% to 5.8%. The Budget was predicting that by July next year it would reach 5.75%. The pre-economic and fiscal outlook revised this up to 6.25%. The Myefo, in a spot of good news, revised this down to 6%. It did however suggest it would rise to 6.25% in 2015. While unemployment did rise sharply in the first half of this year, since June it has pretty much been flat. It would be nice to hope that it will remain flat, but this pause does at least provide some confidence that the 6% prediction is more likely to occur than the previous one of 6.25%: Click here to view on a mobile The biggest issue of the labour market this year however is not that jobs have been declining, but that the increase in employment has been only in part-time jobs. Click here to view on a mobile While part-time work remains the choice of many, this year has seen a quickly widening gap between the unemployment rate of those looking for full-time work and the overall unemployment rate. Currently the full-time unemployment rate is 6% – the highest it has been since the depths of the GFC in 2009. Housing construction The lack of full-time work feeds into the housing market. While housing prices have been increasing this year (almost as much as the growth in articles written about the housing market), as I noted last week, the big growth has come from investors not owner occupiers. As nice as it is to report on auction clearance rates and million dollar houses, a housing boom is only of real benefit to the economy if it is accompanied with an increase in construction. This year saw a growth in housing building approvals – holding steady at 10% annual growth over the past six months. It’s certainly nothing like the first-home buyer stimulus boom seen during the GFC, but it is solid and steady. Click here to view on a mobile Retail spending and consumer confidence The other spending consumers do in shops has also shown signs of a small improvement: Click here to view on a mobile In the past year, total retail spending has grown by 3.4%. Again this is well below what was previously considered average, but at least it’s not the nadir of 2% growth we saw in June. It does however suggest that we remain rather underwhelmed by what is happening in the economy. This is reinforced by the recent consumer confidence data which has shown a fall back to levels observed prior to the election: Click here to view on a mobile This conforms with what I wrote back in July, when I noted that elections have little long-term impact on consumer confidence. People are not dim; they become confident if there are actual reasons to be so, not because a politician tells them to be. This does however put a bit of a dampener on Joe Hockey’s statement in parliament last week that the only things holding up the economy “are the expectations from the community that the Coalition can do it better”. Exchange Rate What remains holding up rather too much is our Australian dollar. For most of the first half it was above parity with the US dollar. Since May, it has fallen to around US$0.90. After a small increase in October and November, it has fallen back to around 90 cents off the back of some pretty strong talk from the Reserve Bank governor, Glenn Stevens. He suggests the true value of the dollar should be around 85 cents: Click here to view on a mobile Inflation This high dollar has helped keep inflation low, as the prices of products we imports (known as “tradeables” in the inflation data) have actually declined in the past 12 months – the prices of audio, visual and computing equipment for example fell 11.3%: Click here to view on a mobile After the rather slight increase due to the introduction of the carbon price, inflation remains well below average – but it is worth noting that this is mostly because of the fall in the tradeables. The Myefo forecasts inflation 2014-15 to be a mere 2% and only 2.25% in the two years after that. If the dollar does fall, this would likely lead to more robust inflation, which in turn would see more robust nominal GDP growth and thus a better budget bottom line. All of which takes us back to the start, and the realisation that while the forecasts in Myefo are sobering, the reality is the government wants them to be sobering. On even the most pessimistic forecast our economy is expected to continue to grow through to the end of 2017. That would take Australia to 26 years straight of continuous growth. To give that some context, not only is it the longest stretch of growth Australians have experienced, the Bank of England has calculated the UK’s GDP going back to 1830. The longest stretch of continuous growth in the 183 years is just 16 years. So let’s not get too down on ourselves this Christmas about the years ahead. • This is my last post for the year as I am taking a few weeks off. I’d like to thank everyone who has read and commented on these posts this year. The discussion has been much appreciated. Have a happy and safe Christmas and see you early in the New Year.

webTitle: FCA: 43% more reports of suspicious trades in wake of Libor-rigging scandal

fields.standfirst: Financial Conduct Authority received 117 self-reported cases of possible distortion and manipulation in a 12-month period
fields.body:
The number of suspicious trades reported to the City regulator has rocketed in the last year, according to official figures. The Financial Conduct Authority said there has been a 43% increase in cases of suspected market rigging since the Libor scandal and a clampdown on rogue traders.

In response to a freedom of information request, the FCA said it had received 117 self-reported cases over a 12-month period of possible distortion and manipulation of various markets, believed to include energy, minerals and financial securities.

The suspicious transaction reports that relate to "the misuse of information", or insider dealing, have increased to more than 1,000, up from 739 in the last equivalent annual period.

Earlier this year the FCA fined day-trading business Swift Trade £8m for moving share prices on the London Stock Exchange by rapidly placing and then cancelling orders on low-trades companies.

The FCA also slapped a £1m fine on stock-market trader, Samuel Nathan Kahn for share "ramping" and before that a £6m penalty on one of India's richest businessmen, Rameshkumar Goenka for market manipulation.

The watchdog said the increase in suspicious transactions was not a sign of increased wrongdoing so much as a greater understanding by traders of their need to be vigilant about their activities.

"The FCA has been working with the industry over the past 18 months to improve the standard of market surveillance undertaken by authorised firms, with a particular focus on increasing the scope of products and behaviours covered," said a spokesman for the City watchdog.

"This, alongside recent actions in relation to market manipulation, such as Swift Trade, Samuel Kahn and Rameshkumar Goenka, have helped firms better understand the types of behaviour we consider manipulative and therefore expect to be reported as suspicious," said the spokesman who believed that Libor fines also contributed to the increased number of potential misconduct.

The FCA said the latest figures on suspicious trades were current up to the end of August but the statistics had not yet been broken down into financial or commodity trades.

There has been increased focus on the regulation of oil and gas trading activities since the FCA and energy watchdog, Ofgem, undertook a probe into wholesale gas trades after reports of suspicious trading on 28 September 2011, from a price reporter and whistleblower, Seth Freedman, who worked for Icis-Heren. An investigation is still being carried out by the European Commission into suspected oil price collusion by BP, Shell and Statoil.

Companies have long been under obligation to self-report any potentially fraudulent trading activities they detected in their own organisations, but in previous years they have been slow to do so.

More publicity along with growing fines have made banks, energy companies and other trading houses aware their chances of being treated more leniently are much improved if they are shown to be proactive, say industry experts.

"Regulated businesses now know just how seriously regulators and politicians will treat market manipulation – they know that they can only expect leniency if they report proactively suspected cases of market manipulation that they come across," said Mark Spiers, head of wealth management at regulatory consultancy Bovill.

"The FCA has really clamped down on banks and individuals for a range of offences from manipulating oil futures to global depository receipts in the past year, as well as taking action against those who have allowed it to take place such as brokers and even compliance officers."

"It is sending out a clear reminder of the tough line it is prepared to take, not just towards the perpetrators themselves but anyone who fails in their duty to take appropriate steps to prevent others from committing market abuse."

This year the FCA has also issued fines for a number of manipulation offences including a £598,000 fine in July against US-based trader Michael Coscia for manipulating oil futures and the price of other commodities, such as wheat and soya beans.

In August it also fined a broker and compliance officer £46,000 and £70,000 apiece for actions enabling market abuse of securities traded on the London Stock Exchange by a Dubai-based private investor.

Royal Bank of Scotland was hit with a €391m (£324m) fine earlier this month after a European Commission investigation into Libor rigging that has seen eight major financial institutions hit with penalties totalling €1.7bn.

Barclays was fined £290m last year and its chairman and chief executive resigned after some of the bank's derivative traders were found to have rigged Libor.
